instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Arrived with coffee damage. Prior repair shop cleaned the board before arriving here so this one will suck. Currently stuck at 5v. <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> areas look spotless

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTX</SIGNAL> only 0.065v, no short

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is shorted. Injected 1v but nothing was warm

What to check next ???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
On T2 machines, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is the first voltage required.
Exact ohm value for the short?
Compare with the readings on all big coils; pay atention to CPU coils.
Remove CPU heatsink and use 20A lab PSU to inject voltage, if is close to pure short.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Diode mode for the short is 0.002.

How much voltage should be injected? Are you suggesting  lab PSU set to 20amps when injecting?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> caps are primarly what were affected by the spill. Can these affect <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
By the name, I would say are in the same PPBUS rail, don't you think?

When inject voltage, let ALWAYS lab PSU at max current limit.
And start injecting with 1V (sometime lower), increasing if needed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Only component getting hot is the GPU. Im assuming this is to new to find a replacement GPU?

Is there a way to retrieve the data if the GPU was removed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Ooops you've injected voltage assuming one of these caps is the culprit?
What if is one of the chips from GPU power supply?

Remove UA710-40 (one by one) and see if/when short disappears from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

0.002 in diode mode could be a good reading; still a chance for GPU to be alive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
beautiful, short disappeared from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

Do you happen to know if these chips are available on similar donar boards or do they need to be  ordered separately??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Check online with Mouser, if you don't have donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: would  sic 635 work replacing sic 621??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Have you had any luck finding these donar boards?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Dificil to get T2 scrap boards; nothing yet on Aliexpress.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Replacement  UA710-40 arrived from digikey. Soldered and short is still gone but still no PPBUS 0v

What to check next??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1.1V drops to .950 and goes back to 1.1V at F7000

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> MUST generate <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> by itself.
Post actual diode mode at F7000.

Remove F7000/1 and check <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> voltage.
If still low, check all resistors and caps around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Post basic voltages, PIN, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET_SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON, <SIGNAL>CBC_ON</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*.
You may need to change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
.365 diode mode

vdda 0v  vddp 5v

<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> .15v

amon  0v

bmon 0v

other voltages are under bga chips. Not sure how to measure those.

all voltages measured with F7000 F7001 removed

Is <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> even available for purchase on this board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Do you get any voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Problems on USB-C areas.
Check diode mode at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> .538

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
For some reason, <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips do not allow input voltage to arrive at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>.
Check voltage and diode mode at LDO rails of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TA_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> 1.5V

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> 0V .489


<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_XA_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> 0V  .493

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_XB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> 0V  .493

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Each chip has 3 more LDO rails.

When you check for voltage, connect charger to corresponding port.
Also test it in the both connection ways.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
UB300

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TA_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> 1.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.4V

UB400

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> 1.5V .491
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.4V  .490

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_TB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> 1.5V

I do not see any further LDO lines that go into the chips. Can you specify what other rails need to be measured???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> is 5v now

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still only 1v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: solved after replacing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
This recently came back for warranty and has the strangest issue. It will be stuck at 5v 0 amps but if measuring <CAPACITOR>C7021</CAPACITOR> with the multi meter it will boot normally at 20v. As soon as the red probe is removed from <CAPACITOR>C7021</CAPACITOR> it goes back to 5V 0 amps.

Any ideas how to fix this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Check the real values of <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22.
Resolder any components related with CSIP/N lines of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

You can also try removing <CAPACITOR>C7021</CAPACITOR>/22.
